docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of Odyssey Healthcare, which provides hospice care for people nearing death, plunged yesterday after the company reduced its profit forecasts and announced that the Justice Department was investigating its operations and charges to Medicare. Odyssey said David C. Gasmire, the chief executive, had resigned. Richard R. Burnham, the chairman, added the chief executive title.

headline.main: Hospice Chain Under Inquiry; Shares Plunge

docs.abstract: Shares of Odyssey Healthcare, which provides hospice care for people nearing death, plunge after company reduces its profit forecasts and announce that Justice Department is investigating its operations and charges to Medicare; company's chief executive David C Gasmire resigns and chairman Richard R Burnham adds chief executive title (M)
docs.snippet: Odyssey Healthcare, which provides hospice care for people nearing death, reduced its profit forecasts and said the Justice Department was investigating its operations.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Rev. Bryan Hooper likes to tell how his Greenwich Village church, Washington Square United Methodist, helped workers in some epic struggles, most notably the Uprising of the 20,000, a three-month walkout by garment workers in 1909 that was the first mass strike by women in American history. The Village has changed a great deal since, but Mr. Hooper wants his congregation to uphold its tradition of helping workers, so it has joined an unusual campaign, called It Takes the Village, which seeks to improve the lives of workers, especially retail workers, in the neighborhood.

headline.main: Neighbors Take Up Cause Of Higher Pay At Some Stores

docs.abstract: Residents of Greenwich Village, Bushwick and Park Slope have begun campaigns to improve lives of workers, especially retail workers, in their neighborhoods; are threatening boycotts, writing letters to store owners and inviting workers to speak to congregations and coffeehouses; are urging retailers to raise workers' wages, provide better health plans and make it easier for workers to unionize; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Rev. Bryan Hooper likes to tell how his Greenwich Village church, Washington Square United Methodist, helped workers in some epic struggles, most notably the Uprising of the 20,000, a three-month walkout by garment workers in 1909 that was the...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''If It's Jazz, Doctors Win, Hands Down'' (NYC column, Oct. 12): The medical profession is liberally populated with amateur classical musicians, too, namely pianists. As a classical piano teacher, I have often seen my medical maladies set aside by doctors for questions about their musical maladies.
docs.abstract: Jocelyn Ruth Krieger letter on doctor-musicians reports that as classical piano teacher she has often seen her medical maladies set aside by doctors with questions about their musical maladies

docs.lead_paragraph: AS the founder of the 008 Investment Club in New York, Diane Terman Felenstein had to learn all about money. That was a big deal. Before she started the club, she said, her financial knowledge was ''nonexistent.'' But that was 1995. She would soon become well acquainted with stock portfolios, insurance and estate planning. The 008 club, which was for women only, inspired ''The Money Club,'' a book published by Simon & Schuster in 1998 that landed on various best-seller lists. By the time the group disbanded in 2000, Ms. Terman Felenstein had a wealth of fiscal knowledge.

headline.main: Grandparents Helping Grandparents Help the Grandkids

docs.abstract: Diane Terman Felenstein uses financial skills from founding 008 Investment Club in 1995 to help lower-income grandparents who are raising grandchildren; her group Grandparents for Grandparents, twenty New York-area women, discusses grandparenting issues with experts and invests money on which profits go to charities helping grandparents; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The 008 Investment Club in New York aims to help lower-income grandparents who are raising grandchildren.

docs.lead_paragraph: American military commanders in Iraq are warning civilian leaders in Washington that delays in reconstruction projects caused by red tape are putting the lives of their troops at risk and undermining the military mission in Iraq. From the junior officer level up through the senior ranks, these officers have outlined obstacles that they say frustrate the rebuilding just as much as the roadside bombs and terrorist attacks that are the more visible threats. They have argued to the new American Embassy in Baghdad and to Congressional delegations visiting Iraq that certain regulations are a dangerous impediment to the military's mission.

headline.main: Iraq Commanders Warn That Delays in Civil Projects Undermine Military Mission

docs.snippet: American officers in Iraq have argued to the new American Embassy in Baghdad that certain regulations are an impediment to the military's mission.

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Medical Association says the government should negotiate directly with drug manufacturers to secure lower prices on prescription medicines for the nation's elderly. Under the new Medicare law, signed by President Bush last December, 41 million elderly and disabled people will have access to drug benefits in 2006. Medicare will rely on private health plans to deliver the benefits. The law says the government ''may not interfere'' in negotiations with drug companies.

headline.main: A.M.A. Says Government Should Negotiate on Drugs

docs.snippet: The American Medical Association says the government should negotiate directly with drug manufacturers to secure lower prices on prescription medicines for the nation's elderly.

docs.lead_paragraph: REPRESENTATIVE JOHN LINDER, Republican of Georgia, is a man on a mission. He wants to replace the current tax system -- or at least personal income and payroll taxes -- with a national sales tax. When he brought this idea to the floor of the House of Representatives a couple of weeks ago, Democrats chided it as a pipe dream. But in August, President Bush called it ''the kind of interesting idea that we ought to explore seriously.'' From a taxpayer's perspective, it may indeed sound like a great idea: no more long instruction booklet to read, no more endless hours calculating the figures for every box on the form; you just pay at the cash register. Yet when it comes to designing such a new system, it's not quite as simple as it sounds.

headline.main: What If a Sales Tax Were the Only Tax?

docs.abstract: Daniel Altman column on proposal by Republican Repr John Linder to replace current tax system, or ast least personal and income taxes, with national sales tax; graph comparing similar VAT levies in other countries (M)
docs.snippet: Does replacing personal income and payroll taxes with a national sales tax, an idea President Bush has shown interest in, help the U.S. tax system?

docs.lead_paragraph: In a bid to avert a state teachers' strike, the State House of Representatives unanimously approved a $160 million plan to provide cut-rate health insurance coverage to state workers. The plan, passed Thursday, would offer workers lower premiums and deductibles compared with a proposal from Gov. Ernie Fletcher, a Republican, that would triple insurance costs for 229,000 retired and active state workers starting in January. Lawmakers will continue to meet next week in a special session to hammer out a plan. Albert Salvato (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Insurance Plan For State Workers

docs.lead_paragraph: Wisconsin has never been a happy hunting ground for politicians named Bush. But President Bush was back in the state yesterday, as was Senator John Kerry, the two men foraging furiously for a last few additional votes in a state where their contest is agonizingly close. In 1988 and 1992, George Bush was outpolled in Wisconsin, first by Michael S. Dukakis and then by Bill Clinton. Four years ago, one of the most popular politicians in the state's history, Tommy G. Thompson, who was governor, confidently predicted that George W. Bush would carry the state.

headline.main: Despite a Razor-Thin Loss in 2000, G.O.P. Again Forecasts a Victory in Wisconsin

docs.snippet: Wisconsin has never been a happy hunting ground for politicians named Bush, but President Bush was back in the state campaigning on Friday, as was Senator John Kerry.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John Kerry painted a dire picture of a second Bush term on Friday, telling Wisconsin voters that the middle class ''simply can't afford four more years'' of the president's economic policies and warning of a ''great potential'' for a return of the military draft should the administration continue to ''go it alone'' in Iraq. In an interview published Friday in The Des Moines Register, Mr. Kerry declared: ''With George Bush, the plan for Iraq is more of the same and the great potential of the draft. Because if we go it alone, I don't know how you do it with the current overextension'' of the armed forces.

headline.main: Kerry Attacks on Economy and a Draft

docs.snippet: Senator John Kerry told Wisconsin voters that the middle class "simply can't afford four more years" of the president's economic policies.
